content.description: A pitch with very few straightforward moves, highlighted by two sustained technical cruxes.  Bring your whole bag of tricks: the route has pinches, crimps, gastons, toe hooks, shallow stems, long lock-off reaches, and a finger crack section to finish it all off.
content.location: Once at the base of the cliff, head left and up on a ledge system.  See beta photo.

content.description:
Skyshine currently ends at rap rings about 60 feet up where a crack peters out.  The route will be extended in the future, but the anchors will be left to provide a nice moderate trad route.

Climb past a low bolt and mantle onto a column top. Climb a fun, right-leaning corner crack from there.  Don't worry about what looks like an off-width pod halfway up.  There's a huge jug that lets you bypass it without any nastiness. The crack is all fingers and hands.
content.protection: Great protection.  A light rack of TCUs up to a #1 Camalot is fine.  1 bolt at the start.
content.location: Once at the base of the Main Wall, turn left.  Skyshine starts off the ramp leading to the ledge below the left side of the wall.

content.description: A varied route with good climbing throughout.  Start with a 12-foot handcrack to the top of a small column, then step right and lieback up a pillar.  The first crux involves bearhugging a flange to a series of powerful sidepull and edge cranks with smears for feet.  This leads to a prominent stembox (5.10) capped by a roof.  The roof is the second crux, which--depending on how you're set up for it--might seem harder or easier than the first crux.  The route ends with face climbing up an arete/ramp feature, finishing with an exposed stemming move.
content.location: Left side of main wall, starts off the ledge.  See beta photo.
